Situation1: They occasionally participate in family traditions during holidays and gatherings.
Expectation2: Maintain passenger safety and provide assistance during service.
Situation2: A report has come in about a suspicious, unattended bag in one of the train cars.
Story:
I was supposed to be at my parents’ house tonight, helping set up for our annual family dinner. My mother had called twice already, reminding me to bring the special dish my grandmother used to make. It was a tradition, one I’d never missed, and I could hear the hope in her voice that I’d be there on time, upholding the values she’d worked so hard to instill in me.

But as the subway rumbled beneath the city, my radio crackled with urgency. “Unattended bag reported in car three. Possible threat. Operator, please respond.” My heart thudded. I knew the protocol—secure the train, alert the authorities, keep the passengers calm. Their safety was in my hands, and every second counted.

I glanced at the clock. If I acted now, I’d be late for dinner, maybe miss it entirely. If I left it to someone else, I’d betray the trust placed in me as an operator. My phone buzzed again—my mother, no doubt checking if I was on my way. I stood at the edge of two worlds, torn between the warmth of family tradition and the cold responsibility of duty, feeling the weight of both pressing in on me.
